questions.answer_description:
Each AWS S3 bucket and object has an ACL (Access Control List) associated with it. An ACL is a list of grants identifying the grantee and the permission granted.
The user can use ACLs to grant basic read/write permissions to other AWS accounts. ACLs use an Amazon S3ג€"specific XML schema. The user cannot grant permissions to other users (IAM users) in his account.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
In AWS, IAM (Identity and Access Management) is the recommended way to manage access to AWS resources, including S3 buckets. IAM provides fine-grained control over permissions and allows administrators to define policies that specify what actions a user can perform on specific resources.

Bucket ACLs, on the other hand, are a legacy way of managing access control in S3 and are not designed to grant access to IAM users directly. Bucket ACLs are used to grant permissions to individual AWS accounts or predefined groups, but they do not work with IAM users.
C. It is not possible to give access to an IAM user using ACL

This answer should be as below.
C. It is not possible to give access to other IAM user using ACL

choices.C: It is not possible to give access to an IAM user using ACL
choices.D: The IAM user can perform all operations on the bucket using only API/SDK
choices.A: He can just view the content of the bucket
choices.B: He can do all the operations on the bucket

questions.question_text: A root account owner has given full access of his S3 bucket to one of the IAM users using the bucket ACL. When the IAM user logs in to the S3 console, which actions can he perform?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
When facing a memory issue causing high CPU utilization in an application, the user may want to investigate the root cause without triggering any scaling activity. In this scenario, suspending the scaling process allows the user to temporarily halt any scaling actions triggered by Auto Scaling policies.

By suspending the scaling process, the Auto Scaling group will no longer automatically launch or terminate instances based on scaling policies. This gives the user the opportunity to investigate the issue within the application without interference from scaling activities.

Once the user has completed the research and resolved the root cause of the memory issue, they can resume the scaling process to allow Auto Scaling to function as intended.
D. Suspend the scaling process until research is completed

questions.answer_description: Auto Scaling allows the user to suspend and then resume one or more of the Auto Scaling processes in the Auto Scaling group. This is very useful when the user wants to investigate a configuration problem or some other issue, such as a memory leak with the web application and then make changes to the application, without triggering the Auto Scaling process.

choices.D: Suspend the scaling process until research is completed
choices.B: It is not possible to find the root cause from that instance without triggering scaling
choices.A: Stop the scaling process until research is completed
choices.C: Delete Auto Scaling until research is completed

questions.question_text:
An organization has configured Auto Scaling with ELB. There is a memory issue in the application which is causing CPU utilization to go above 90%. The higher
CPU usage triggers an event for Auto Scaling as per the scaling policy. If the user wants to find the root cause inside the application without triggering a scaling activity, how can he achieve this?
A sys admin is planning to subscribe to the RDS event notifications. For which of the below mentioned source categories the subscription cannot be configured?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
You cannot configure event notifications specifically for DB options groups. Event notifications for options groups are not available as a separate source category.

questions.answer_description: Amazon RDS uses the Amazon Simple Notification Service (SNS. to provide a notification when an Amazon RDS event occurs. These events can be configured for source categories, such as DB instance, DB security group, DB snapshot and DB parameter group.

questions.question_text: A user has launched an EC2 instance. The instance got terminated as soon as it was launched. Which of the below mentioned options is not a possible reason for this?

choices.D: The user account has reached the maximum volume limit
choices.A: The user account has reached the maximum EC2 instance limit
choices.C: The AMI is missing. It is the required part

questions.answer_description:
When the user account has reached the maximum number of EC2 instances, it will not be allowed to launch an instance. AWS will throw an
'InstanceLimitExceeded' error. For all other reasons, such as ג€AMI is missing partג€, ג€Corrupt Snapshotג€ or ג€Volume limit has reachedג€ it will launch an EC2 instance and then terminate it.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
The EC2 immediately terminate by following reason:
- You've exceeded your EBS volume limits. For more information, see Instance volume limits.
- An EBS snapshot is corrupted.
- The root EBS volume is encrypted and you do not have permissions to access the KMS key for decryption.
- A snapshot specified in the block device mapping for the AMI is encrypted and you do not have permissions to access the KMS key for decryption or you do not have access to the - -KMS key to encrypt the restored volumes.
- The instance store-backed AMI that you used to launch the instance is missing a required part (an image.part.xx file).

ref: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/troubleshooting-launch.html#troubleshooting-launch-internal

Correct Answer: A 
https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/troubleshooting-launch.html#troubleshooting-launch-internal
The question states that the instance got terminated as soon as it is launched.
Options B, C, and D can be a reason for this. But we need to know which one of these is not a reason for this behavior. Option A is the answer because if we have reached the maximum number of EC2 instance it won't even launch the instance.
A. The user account has reached the maximum EC2 instance limit

questions.question_text:
A user is trying to understand the detailed CloudWatch monitoring concept. Which of the below mentioned services does not provide detailed monitoring with
CloudWatch?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
CloudWatch provides basic monitoring for Route53, allowing users to monitor metrics such as query latency and query count. However, it does not provide detailed monitoring for Route53.

comments.content: AWS EMR allows users to enable detailed monitoring for their clusters, which provides more frequent and granular metrics collection. With detailed monitoring enabled, CloudWatch collects additional metrics at a 1-minute frequency, compared to the default 5-minute frequency.

questions.answer_description: CloudWatch is used to monitor AWS as well as the custom services. It provides either basic or detailed monitoring for the supported AWS products. In basic monitoring, a service sends data points to CloudWatch every five minutes, while in detailed monitoring a service sends data points to CloudWatch every minute. Services, such as RDS, EC2, Auto Scaling, ELB, and Route 53 can provide the monitoring data every minute.
